text:
Introduction
Indeed, praise be to Allah. We praise Him, seek His help, and ask for His forgiveness. We seek refuge in Allah from the evils of our souls and the bad consequences of our deeds. Whoever Allah guides, there is no one to misguide him, and whoever He misguides, there is no guide for him. I bear witness that there is no deity but Allah alone, having no partner. And I bear witness that Muhammad is His servant and Messenger, may Allah bless him, his family, and his companions and grant them peace.
To proceed:
This is the first part of the book "Al-Ukhuwwah (1) wa Al-Akhawat" (Brothers and Sisters) by Imam Al-Daraqutni. I present it—today—to the brothers, researchers, and students of knowledge. Before this, I had edited the book "Al-Ikhwah Alladhina Ruwiya 'Anhum Al-Hadith" (The Brothers From Whom Hadith Was Narrated) by Abu Dawood Al-Sijistani, and the book "Tasmiyat Man Ruwiya 'Anhu Min Awlad Al-Asharah" (Naming Those From Whom Narrations Were Reported Among the Children of the Ten [Promised Paradise]) by Imam Ali bin Al-Madini, which contains a large section on brothers and sisters who have narrations; I published them in one volume and named it "Al-Ruwat Min Al-Ikhwah wa Al-Akhawat" (The Narrators Among Brothers and Sisters).
This book is specific in mentioning brothers among the Companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, those who narrated from him, or saw him and did not narrate from him, or were born in his era, or whose brother was born after the death of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, from both men and women.

It differs from the two previous books in the following ways:
1 - This book is specific to the Sahaba (Companions), whereas the previous two books are general regarding all narrators, including Sahaba, Tabi'in (Followers), Atba' al-Tabi'in (Followers of the Followers), and others.
2 - This book includes all Sahaba, whether they were narrators or not, whereas the previous two books are specific to narrators of Hadith.
3 - Al-Daraqutni provides brief and useful biographical notes for the names he mentions, whereas in the previous two books, there are no biographies for the narrators.
4 - Al-Daraqutni mentioned Hadiths in his book, some with his chain of transmission (Isnad) and others without Isnad, whereas in the previous two books, no Hadiths were mentioned, except for a few Hadiths at the end of Ali bin Al-Madini's book which are additions by Ibn Al-Daqqaq and not from the narration of Ali bin Al-Madini.

My Work on the Book:
1 - I verified the text; I exerted my effort in adjusting the text and producing it sound and correct.
2 - I wrote brief biographies for all the (Brothers) mentioned in the book.
3 - I documented the text by referring to books of genealogy, Rijal (narrators), classes (Tabaqat), and biographies.
4 - I extracted (Takhrij) the Hadiths found in the book.
5 - I mentioned a number of sources for each biography mentioned in the book, limiting myself to

Brief Definition of Imam Al-Daraqutni (1):
Much has been written about this Imam in terms of individual research and university dissertations (2), so I will limit myself to a brief introduction of this Imam:
He is: "The Imam, the Hafiz, the Master, Sheikh al-Islam, the Flagship of Critical Scholars, Abu Al-Hasan Ali bin Umar bin Ahmed bin Mahdi bin Masud bin Al-Nu'man bin Dinar bin Abdullah Al-Baghdadi, the Reciter, the Muhaddith, from the people of the Dar Al-Qutn locality in Baghdad. He was born in the year three hundred and six."
Al-Dhahabi said in "Al-Siyar": "He was one of the oceans of knowledge, and one of the Imams of the world. He reached the pinnacle in memorization and knowledge of the defects ('Illal) of Hadith and its narrators, along with proficiency in Qira'at (Recitations) and their paths, and strength of participation

Description of the Manuscript:
I relied in the verification on a unique photocopied manuscript from the Chester Beatty Library in Ireland. I obtained it from the Imam Muhammad bin Saud Islamic University Library, Manuscripts Department. This manuscript consists of eight folios, each folio having two sides, and each side containing (8 - 19) lines. It is narrated with Isnad (chain of transmission) as stated in the first paper, and it has hearing certificates (Sama'at) on the last paper as will come, Allah willing.
What exists of this valuable book is only the first part. I have searched for the rest of the book but have not found it yet. May Allah, Glory be to Him and the Most High, facilitate finding the rest of the book.
A gap (omission) occurred in this part in its middle on the fifth folio. This gap is at the end of the biography of the brothers from the children of Al-Abbas bin Abd al-Muttalib, and from the beginning of the biography of Abu Bakr and his children. I estimate this gap to be about two folios, and Allah knows best.

Validity of Attributing the Book to Al-Daraqutni:
I assert that this book is authored by Al-Daraqutni for the following reasons:
1 - The Isnad at the beginning of the book indicates that.
2 - The Isnads inside the book; Al-Daraqutni narrated them from his Sheikhs; such as in biography number (33) where he said: "Yahya bin Muhammad bin Sa'id told us this..." and he is one of Al-Daraqutni's Sheikhs.
3 - Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar quoted many places from this book in "Al-Isabah" and in "Al-Tahdhib", and they are found in this book exactly:
See for example in "Tahdhib Al-Tahdhib" (8/362, 421), (11/72), and in "Al-Isabah" in the biography of Tammam bin Al-Abbas (1/376). And in the biography of Rabi'ah bin Al-Harith bin Abd al-Muttalib (1/376). And in the biography of Abdullah bin Al-Harith bin Abd al-Muttalib (2/462). And in the biography of Hind bin Abi Hala (6/558). And in the biography of Nawfal bin Al-Harith (6/480). And in the biography of Arwa bint Rabi'ah (7/479). And in the biography of Umamah bint Abi Al-As (7/504). And in the biography of Hind bint Atiq (8/157).

text: As for Nawfal, his Kunya is Abu Al-Harith (1), and he was older (2) than his uncles Hamza and Al-Abbas, and all his brothers. He was among those who remained steadfast (3) with the Prophet, peace be upon him, on the Day of Hunayn. He did not narrate anything (4), and he died two years (5) after the beginning of the caliphate of Umar bin Al-Khattab in Medina and was buried in Al-Baqi'. He is the grandfather of Babbah (6). As for Rabi'ah bin Al-Harith, his Kunya is Abu Arwa, and he was older (7) than his uncle Al-Abbas. He narrated
foot_note:

2. In "Al-Isabah": Al-Zubayr bin Bakkar said: He was the oldest of Banu Hashim to embrace Islam, even older than his uncles Hamza and Al-Abbas.

This was mentioned in the biography of Al-Mughira bin Nawfal. Al-Daraqutni said in the book "Al-Ikhwah": Nawfal bin Al-Harith died in the caliphate of Umar, two years after it began, in Medina, and he did not narrate anything. In "Al-Siyar": I do not know of any narration for him.
5. In "Al-Tabaqat": Nawfal died one year and three months after Umar became caliph. Umar prayed over him, followed him to Al-Baqi', and he was buried there.

7. In "Al-Tabaqat" and "Al-Siyar" they said: Rabi'ah bin Al-Harith was older than his uncle Al-Abbas by two years.

Abu Sufyan bin Al-Harith died in the year twenty (2), and Umar bin Al-Khattab prayed over him. As for Abdullah bin Al-Harith bin Abd al-Muttalib; he embraced Islam and his name was Abd Shams, so the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, named him (3) Abdullah! Ibn Umar said: If Ibn Abbas had reached our age, none of us would have been able to associate with him [due to his superior knowledge]. He is one of the prolific narrators among the Companions and one of the 'Abdullahs' (Abadilah) among the jurists of the Companions. "Tabaqat Ibn Sa'd" (2/365), "Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir" (5/3), "Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil" (5/116), "Al-Ahad wa Al-Mathani" (1/284), "Usud Al-Ghabah" (3/290), "Al-Siyar" (3/331), "Al-Isabah" (4/141), "Al-Tahdhib" (5/276).
35 - From the younger Companions, he was generous and giving. "Al-Ma'rifah wa Al-Tarikh" (3/322), "Usud Al-Ghabah" (3/524), "Al-Ahad wa Al-Mathani" (1/296), "Al-Siyar" (3/512), "Tahdhib Al-Kamal" (2/789), "Al-Isabah" (4/396), "Al-Tahdhib" (7/19).
36 - Qutham - with a Damma on the Qaf and Fatha on the Tha - a young Companion who died in the year fifty-seven. "Al-Tabaqat Al-Kubra" (7/367), "Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir" (7/194), "Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil" (7/145), "Al-Ahad wa Al-Mathani" (1/294), "Usud Al-Ghabah" (4/392), "Al-Siyar" (3/440), "Al-Isabah" (5/420), "Al-Tahdhib" (8/361).
37 - From the younger children of Abbas. "Usud Al-Ghabah" (5/220), "Al-Siyar" (3/442), "Al-Isabah" (6/236).
38 - In "Al-Isabah": One of the brothers. Mus'ab Al-Zubayri said: He was born during the time of the Prophet, peace be upon him, and was martyred in Ifriqiya. "Usud Al-Ghabah" (3/466), "Al-Isabah" (5/40).

text: 39 - And Umm Habib (1); their mother (2) is Umm Al-Fadl (3) Lubabah bint Al-Harith bin Hazn Al-Hilaliyyah. 40 - And Tammam. ... 41 - And Kathir. The sons of Al-Abbas from a (4) mother of a child (Umm Walad).
foot_note:
1. 39 - In "Al-Isabah": Umm Habib or Umm Habibah, the former is more famous. She saw the Prophet. "Al-Tabaqat Al-Kubra" (8/49), "Usud Al-Ghabah" (7/313), "Al-Isabah" (8/186).
1. In "Al-Isabah": Abu Umar said: Her mother is Umm Al-Fadl, so she is the full sister of Al-Fadl and Abdullah.
2. In "Al-Siyar" (2/314): The wife of Al-Abbas and the mother of his six noble male children.
3. She is the sister of the Mother of the Believers Maymunah, the maternal aunt of Khalid bin Al-Walid, and the maternal sister of Asma bint Umays. She died after Al-Abbas during the caliphate of Uthman. "Al-Tabaqat Al-Kubra" (8/277), "Usud Al-Ghabah" (7/253), "Al-Siyar" (2/314), "Al-Isabah" (8/276), "Al-Tahdhib" (12/449).
40 - Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Isabah" (1/375): Ibn Al-Sakan said: It is said: He was the youngest of his brothers and the most physically powerful of Quraysh. No narration from the Prophet, peace be upon him, is preserved for him via a confirmed route. "Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir" (2/157), "Usud Al-Ghabah" (1/253), "Al-Siyar" (3/443), "Al-Isabah" (1/375), "Ta'jil Al-Manfa'ah" (43).
41 - Al-Dhahabi said in "Al-Siyar": He was a jurist, majestic, righteous, and trustworthy. He had no offspring. In "Al-Isabah": Al-Daraqutni said in the book "Al-Ikhwah": He narrated Mursal hadiths from the Prophet, peace be upon him. "Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir" (7/207), "Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil" (7/153), "Usud Al-Ghabah" (4/460), "Al-Siyar" (3/443), "Al-Isabah" (5/634), "Al-Tahdhib" (8/420).
4. Ibn Al-Athir said in "Usud Al-Ghabah" (1/253) in the biography of Tammam: His mother was a Roman Umm Walad, and Kathir is his full brother. Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Isabah" (1/375) in the biography of Tammam: His mother was an Umm Walad, and said in the biography of Kathir (5/634): His mother was Roman, and it is said: Himyari.

publisher: Dar Al-Rayah for Publishing and Distribution, Riyadh - Saudi Arabia
text: 42 - And Al-Harith bin Al-Abbas, his mother was from Hudhayl (1). 43 - And Amina. 44 - And Safiyyah. 45 - And Umm Kulthum; daughters of Al-Abbas from mothers of children (Umm Walad). Hisham Ibn Al-Kalbi said: 46 - And Subayh. 47 - And Mushir, sons of Al-Abbas, but he was not followed in that.
foot_note:
1. 42 - Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Isabah" (2/151): Abu Umar said: All of Al-Abbas's children saw the Prophet, but companionship is for Al-Fadl and Abdullah. It is said: His father got angry with him and expelled him, so he joined Al-Zubayr, who then came and interceded for him with his maternal uncle Al-Abbas. "Usud Al-Ghabah" (1/401).
1. Ibn Al-Athir said in "Usud Al-Ghabah" (1/401): His mother was a woman from Hudhayl. In "Al-Isabah" (2/151): His mother was Hujayla bint Jundab bin Al-Rabi' Al-Hilaliyyah, and it is said: an Umm Walad.
43 - Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Isabah" (7/533): Al-Daraqutni mentioned her in "Al-Ikhwah" and said: Al-Abbas bin Utbah bin Abi Lahab married her, and she bore him Al-Fadl bin Al-Abbas, the famous poet.
44 - Ibn Al-Athir did not mention her in "Usud Al-Ghabah" nor Al-Hafiz in "Al-Isabah". She was mentioned in "Al-Tabaqat Al-Kubra" (4/6) in the biography of her father Al-Abbas, and also in "Jamharat Ansab Al-Arab" (265), stating she was the wife of Al-Harith bin Ya'mar.
45 - In "Usud Al-Ghabah" (7/385): She lived during the time of the Prophet, peace be upon him, and her mother was Umm Salamah bint Mahmiyah bin Jaz' Al-Zubayri! This is what he said, but Al-Hafiz pointed out in "Al-Isabah" (8/295) that the one whose mother is Umm Salamah is Umm Kulthum bint Al-Fadl bin Al-Abbas.
46 - Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Isabah" (1/376): The brothers are ten: Al-Fadl, Abdullah, Ubaydullah, Qutham, Ma'bad, Abd al-Rahman, Kathir, Subayh, Mushir, and Tammam. All are agreed upon except the eighth and ninth, as Hisham Al-Kalbi was unique in mentioning them. Al-Daraqutni said in "Al-Ikhwah": He is not followed in this.
47 - Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Isabah" (6/260): Abu Bakr bin Durayd counted him among the children of Al-Abbas, and Ibn Fathun added him. Perhaps he was born after Tammam.

publisher: Dar Al-Rayah for Publishing and Distribution, Riyadh - Saudi Arabia
text: Ibrahim Al-Harbi said: 48 - And Lubabah. 49 - And Aminah. Ibn Makhlad narrated this to us from him. As for Al-Fadl; his Kunya is Abu Abdullah (1), and it is said: Abu Muhammad (2). He is the 'Rider' (Al-Ridif) (3). He narrated from the Prophet, peace be upon him. His father (4) Al-Abbas bin Abd al-Muttalib, his brother Abdullah, Abu Hurairah, Abu Al-Tufayl and others narrated from him. The time (5) of his death is disputed; it is said: he was killed during the caliphate of Abu Bakr on the Day of Yarmouk, and it is said: on the Day of Ajnadayn, and it is said: on the Day of Marj Al-Suffar. And it is said: during the caliphate (6) of Umar in
foot_note:
1. 48 - I did not find her biography.

1. Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Isabah": His Kunya was Abu Al-Abbas and Abu Abdullah, and it is said: his Kunya was Abu Muhammad, Ibn Al-Sakan asserted this.
2. Ibn Sa'd used this Kunya for him in "Al-Tabaqat" and Ibn Abi Asim in "Al-Ahad".
3. It came in the "Two Sahihs" and others: That the Prophet, peace be upon him, had him ride behind him during the Farewell Pilgrimage, and he was the one looking at the woman from Khath'am while the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, turned his face to the other side... "Sahih Al-Bukhari" Book of Hajj (3/378), "Sahih Muslim" (2/973).
4. I did not find anyone who said: that his father narrated from him. See "Tahdhib Al-Kamal" (2/1099 - Manuscript section).
5. Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Isabah" (5/376): Al-Waqidi said: He died in the Plague of Amwas, and Al-Zubayr and Ibn Abi Hatim followed him. Ibn Al-Sakan said: He was killed on the Day of Ajnadayn during the caliphate of Abu Bakr, and it is said: Yarmouk.
6. Ibn Sa'd said (4/54): He died in the region of Jordan during the caliphate of Umar. Al-Hafiz said: The first view is the relied upon one, and Al-Bukhari asserted it, saying: He died during the caliphate of Umar bin Al-Khattab. Ibn Abi Asim said in "Al-Ahad wa Al-Mathani" (1/281): He died at the age of twenty-one =

publisher: Dar Al-Rayah for Publishing and Distribution, Riyadh - Saudi Arabia
text: the Plague of Amwas in the Levant in the year eighteen, and Allah knows best. He did not leave any children except Umm Kulthum (1), his daughter. Al-Hasan bin Ali bin Abi Talib married her, then separated from her (2). Then Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari married her, and she bore him Musa (3). He died leaving her a widow, so Imran bin Talha bin Ubaydullah married her. It is said: He left a son called Abdullah, but this is not proven. As for Abdullah bin Al-Abbas; his Kunya is Abu Al-Abbas. He was born in the She'b (4) before Banu Hashim left it, which was three years before the Hijra. The Prophet, peace be upon him, died when he was thirteen (5), and it is said: he was fifteen (6) at the death of the Prophet, peace be upon him. The Prophet, peace be upon him, prayed for him that

6. Al-Tayalisi narrated in his "Musnad" - as in "Al-Minhah" (2/148) -, Ahmad in "Al-Musnad" (1/373), Ibn Abi Asim in "Al-Ahad wa Al-Mathani" (1/284) (No. 372, 373) =

text: Allah gives him understanding (1) in the religion and teaches him interpretation (Ta'wil). His virtues are many, as is his narration. He died in Ta'if in the year sixty-eight (2), and Muhammad bin Al-Hanafiyyah prayed over him (3). Ibn Umar, Jabir, Abu Sa'id, Anas bin Malik, Abu Al-Tufayl, and others narrated from him. As for Ubaydullah bin Al-Abbas, his Kunya is Abu Muhammad. He was younger (4) in age than his brother Abdullah by a year. He narrated from the Prophet, peace be upon him, and Sulayman bin Yasar narrated from him. Ali appointed him governor over Yemen,
foot_note:
1. = Al-Hakim (3/533) and Al-Tabarani (10/289), all of them via Shu'bah from Abu Ishaq from Sa'id bin Jubayr from Ibn Abbas who said: The Messenger of Allah died when I was fifteen years old and I had been circumcised. All its narrators are trustworthy. Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Fath" (11/76): The preserved and correct view is: He was born in the She'b three years before the Hijra, so he would be thirteen years old at the Prophet's death. The biographers were certain of this, and Ibn Abd al-Barr authenticated it.
1. Narrated by Ahmad in "Al-Musnad" (1/266, 314, 335), Al-Fasawi in his "Tarikh" (1/494), Ibn Abi Shaybah in "Al-Musannaf" (12/111), Ibn Sa'd in "Al-Tabaqat" (2/365), Ibn Abi Asim in "Al-Ahad wa Al-Mathani" (1/287), Al-Hakim in "Al-Mustadrak" (3/534), and Al-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" (10/293), all via Ibn Abbas who said: I spent the night in the house of my aunt Maymunah, and I placed water for the Prophet, peace be upon him, for ablution. He said: "Who placed this?" They said: Abdullah. He said: "O Allah, teach him interpretation and give him understanding in the religion." The hadith also has other paths and wordings.
2. Al-Dhahabi said in "Al-Siyar": Ali bin Al-Madini said: Ibn Abbas died in the year sixty-eight or sixty-seven. Al-Waqidi, Al-Haytham, and Abu Nu'aym said: Year sixty-eight. It is said: He lived seventy-one years. In "Al-Isabah" (4/152): They agreed that he died in Ta'if in the year sixty-eight.
3. In "Al-Isabah": Al-Zubayr bin Bakkar said: He died in Ta'if, and Ibn Al-Hanafiyyah prayed over him.
4. Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Isabah" (4/396): He was younger than Abdullah by a year. Mus'ab, Ibn Sa'd, Al-Zubayr, and Ya'qub bin Shaybah said this.

publisher: Dar Al-Rayah for Publishing and Distribution, Riyadh - Saudi Arabia
text: and he was generous and giving (1). He died in Medina (2). As for Qutham bin Al-Abbas, the Prophet, peace be upon him, had him ride behind him (3), and he resembled (4) the Prophet, peace be upon him. Ali bin Abi Talib appointed him governor over Medina (5). Ali, peace be upon him, said: The person with the most recent contact (6) with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, is Qutham bin Al-Abbas. He narrated from the Prophet, peace be upon him. Abu (7) Ishaq Al-Sabi'i narrated from him, saying: I said to Qutham bin Al-Abbas: By what did Ali inherit from the
foot_note:
1. In "Al-Asl": 'an old man' (Shaykhan), and the correct word is what is in "Al-Isabah": Al-Zubayr said: He was generous and giving (Sakhiyan Jawadan)... and Ali appointed him over Yemen, and he led the people in Hajj in the year thirty-six. See "Tarikh Khalifah bin Khayyat" (200).
2. In "Al-Isabah": Khalifah said (225): He died in the year fifty-eight in Medina. Al-Waqidi said: He lived until the time of Yazid bin Mu'awiyah, and Abu Nu'aym asserted this. Abu Ubaydah and Ya'qub bin Shaybah said: He died in the year eighty-seven.
3. Narrated by Ahmad in his "Musnad" (1/205), and Al-Bukhari in his "Tarikh" (7/197) from Abdullah bin Ja'far.
4. In "Al-Isabah": Ibn Al-Sakan and others said: He used to resemble the Prophet, peace be upon him.
5. Al-Dhahabi said in "Al-Siyar": Al-Zubayr bin Bakkar said: Ali appointed him over Medina. Khalifah said in his "Tarikh" (210): He governed Mecca for Ali and remained its governor until Ali was killed. Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Tahdhib": Ibn Abd al-Barr said: He governed Mecca for Ali. Al-Daraqutni asserted in the book "Al-Ikhwah" that Ali appointed him over Medina and appointed his brother Ma'bad over Mecca.
6. Narrated by Ahmad in "Al-Musnad" (1/101), and Ibn Abi Asim in "Al-Ahad wa Al-Mathani" (1/295) from Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The last of the people to have contact with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was Qutham bin Al-Abbas - meaning in his grave.
7. In "Al-Asl": Abi (Genitive case), [Corrected to Abu (Nominative)].

Qutham was martyred (2) in Samarkand during the time of Mu'awiyah, and his grave is there. As for Ma'bad, Ali appointed him governor over Mecca (3), and he was killed as a martyr in Ifriqiya (4), and he has no narration. Among his descendants are Ibrahim and Abbas, the sons of Abdullah (5)... * * * * *

Rahman (1), and Abu Atiq's name is Muhammad; he is the grandfather of Abd al-Rahman and Muhammad, the sons of Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Abd al-Rahman bin Abu Bakr, and Sulayman bin Bilal their freed slave. text: of the two spears (1) - bin Al-Mughira bin Abdullah bin Amr bin Makhzum. He narrated from the Prophet, peace be upon him, and from Abu Bakr. Abu Bakr, Uthman, Ali, Talha, Al-Zubayr, Sa'd, Sa'id, Abd al-Rahman, Ibn Masud, and a large number of Muhajirin and Ansar and others from the Companions of the Prophet, peace be upon him, narrated from him. As for Zaid bin Al-Khattab, his mother is Asma bint Wahb from Banu Asad bin Khuzaymah.
